paragraphs.text: Solid State Communications Mixed valence as a necessary criteria for quasi-two dimensional electron gas in oxide hetero-interfaces

The origin of quasi-two dimensional electron gas at the interface of polar-nonpolar oxide hetero-structure, such as LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 , is debated over electronic reconstruction and defects/disorder models. Common to these models is the partial valence transformation of substrate Ti ions from its equilibrium + state to an itinerant 3 + state. Given that the Hf ions have a lower ionization potential than Ti due to the f orbital screening, one would expect a hetero-interface conductivity in the polar-nonpolar LaAlO /SrHfO 3 system as well. However, our first principles calculations show the converse. Unlike the Ti − Ti 3+ 4+ valence transition which occur at a nominal energy cost, the barrier energy associated with its isoelectronic Hf − Hf 3+ 4+ counterpart is very high, hence suppressing the formation of quasi-two dimensional electron gas at LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 hetero-interface. These calculations, therefore, emphasize on the propensity of mixed valence at the interface as a necessary condition for an oxide hetero-structure to exihibit quasi two-dimensional electron gas.

The origin of quasi-two dimensional electron gas at the interface of LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 and few other perosvkite hetero-structures and super-lattices has been attributed to both intrinsic and extrinsic factors .
Among these, the most fascinating and widely discussed model is that of electronic reconstruction due to polar catastrophe.

According to the model, a polar discontinuity emerges due to the polar (LaAlO ) and non-polar (TiO 2 terminated SrTiO 3 ) interface , leading to a potential build-up which concomitantly increase with increasing LaAlO 3 film thickness.

In case of an abrupt interface, i.e., devoid of defects and disorder, electronic stability at the interface is accom- plished by a charge transfer from the LaAlO 3 surface to the interface TiO 2 layer of the SrTiO 3 substrate, thereby leading to a superposition of Ti 4+ and Ti 3+ states at the interface.
The extra electron in the d 3 band of Ti 3+ render the hetero-interface conductivity.
The picture is well justified in terms of spectroscopy and band structure calculations .
With increasing film thickness, the valence O p 2 bands emanating from the LaAlO 3 surface move towards the Fermi energy until it overlaps with the SrTiO 3 conduction band.

The orbital overlap occurs at a certain critical thickness of the LaAlO 3 film, below which the polar discontinuity appears to be alleviated by field induced polar distortions in the near-interface layers of SrTiO 3 .

Simplest among the alternate mechanisms to the polar catastrophe model that lead to quasi-two dimensional conductivity at the interface of oxide heterostructures is the defect/disorder models . Following the growth process, such as the pulsed laser deposition technique, it may be well assumed that this high energy synthesis would facilitate La 3+ /Sr 2+ and/or Al 3+ /Ti 4+ inter-mixing at the inter- face thereby reducing the extent of polar catastrophe at the interface . Beyond, defects in the form of oxygen vacancies, the concentra- tion of which depends sensitively on the growth parameters, also tend to modify the interface structure and electronic properties . For example, an oxygen vacancy holds its equivalence to two extrinsically doped electrons into the system which could also alleviate the polar discontinuity at the interface. Thus, based on simple valence argu- ments, defects in the form of oxygen vacancies and/or inter-site cation disorder would also induce electronic conductivity via the superposi- tion of Ti 3+ and Ti 4+ states at the interface. Apart from these extrinsic effects, it is also proposed that lattice instabilities could also drive the LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 interface conducting . In general, both intrinsic (polar discontinuity) and extrinsic (defects and disorder) mechanisms are expected to play an important role in driving the hetero-interface towards instability.

Thus, irrespective of the above models, the origin of quasi-two dimensional electron gas (q-2DEG) in oxide hetero-structures, seem to be a facilitation of mixed valence states of the Ti transition metal at the interface . Moreover, the relative stability of the Ti 3+ valence state is fairly high, as is being evidenced by phase diagrams, where SrTiO 3 form a continuous solid solutions with electron doping(the case of La substitutions at the Sr site). Beyond, the high structural stability of SrTiO 3 withstanding oxygen vacancies as high as 10% and also the large oxygen ionic mobility in SrTiO 3 could be well associated to the intrinsic chemical property of the Ti ions via valence regulation between its energetically favorable 3 + and 4 + states. Along these perspectives, it then becomes rudimentary to check for the necessary and sufficient conditions in oxide hetero-interface conductivity, direc- ted towards the role of multiple valence states of the substrate.
The propensity of an ion to exhibit multiple valence states in group IV B of the periodic table decrease down the group.
In this regard, we consider the LaAlO 3 /SrXO 3 oxide hetero-structures with XO 2 termina- tion of the substrate, X ≡Ti and Hf.
In this isoelectronic class of systems, the stability of Ti in its +3 and +4 states in SrTiO 3 are ubiquitous , while the propensity of Hf exhibiting multiple valence states is little known.
It is also worthy to mention that SrTiO 3 accommodate chemical substitutions at both Sr and Ti sites forming a complete solid solutions, while such cases tend to be very limited for SrHfO 3 .

Hence, based on these observations and, considering that the electronic conductivity in oxide hetero-structures proportionate with the concentration of interface mixed valence states, one would then expect a steady decline in the transport properties as the transition metal in SrXO 3 substrate is replaced from Ti to Hf.

On the other hand, comparison of the ionization energies of Ti (≃6.8 eV) and Hf (≃5.9 eV) shows that the latter have lower ionization energy due to the lanthanide contraction, where the f electrons screen the positive nuclear charge from the outer d 5 valence electrons.

In this pretext, one may then expect a q-2DEG at the hetero-interface of LaAlO /SrHfO 3 , similar to that of its isoelectronic LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 counterpart, which would then reveal a rare instance of Hf ions in the non-equilibrium +3 state.

To illustrate that the necessary condition to impart a q-2DEG at an abrupt hetero-interface is electronic reconstruction of the transition metal ions, we adopt to the first-principles calculations based on density functional theory (DFT). The DFT approach to the problem has remained quite successful in illustrating the hetero-interface conductivity of LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 . The calculations were carried out using the full-potential linearized augmented plane-wave (FP-LAPW) meth- od, as implemented in the WIEN2k suite of programs . The hetero- structures were modeled by stacking five unit cells of SrXO with XO 2 termination (X ≡Ti, Hf) as substrate while the LaAlO film was assigned four unit-cells thickness. The structural dimension of the hetero-structure was a a c √2 × √2 × , with a=3.905 and 4.117 Å for the LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 and LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 substrates, respectively and c=9a. The periodic images of the system is further separated by a vacuum separation of 55 Å. This geometry provides an extra degree of freedom to the surface ions to relax outwards while equilibrating the internal ionic coordinates with minimum forces between the ions. The ex- change-correlation potential was described in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). Convergence in the basis set was achieved with RK = 7 max , R being the smallest LAPW sphere radius and K max being the interstitial plane-wave cutoff. The sphere radii, in Bohr units, for Sr/La, Ti/Hf, and O were chosen as 2.2, 1.9, and 1.6, respectively. Convergence of the Brillouin zone (BZ) sampling is achieved for a a Monkhorst-Pack k-mesh of dimension 15 × 15 × 2, equivalent to 72 k-points in the irreducible region of the BZ.
In we show the band structure of LaAlO /SrTiO 3 3 and LaAlO /SrHfO 3 hetero-structures.
The conduction bands of LaAlO /SrHfO 3 are comprised of the Ti d 3 states of the SrTiO 3 substrate, while the valence band is predominantly O p 2 in character.
However, the interesting feature that merges from the site-decomposed orbital projection of the band structure shows that the bottom of the valence band (E E − < 2eV F

, not shown) is mainly composed of the O p 2 bands emanating from the SrTiO 3 substrate, while the top ( E E −2 eV < < F ) is predominantly of those emanating from the AlO 2 layers of the LaAlO 3 motif.
The weight factor in the distribution of the AlO 2 derived O p 2 states, however, increase in energy as one moves from the interface towards the surface.
The bands that cross the Fermi energy are those of the O 2p states of the surface AlO 2 layer.
Similarly, we also find a layer by layer distribution of Ti d 3 energy states in the conduction band.
We note that the Ti d 3 states of bulk SrTiO 3 are >3.2 eV ( E ≡ g ; the band gap) are above the valence band maximum.

However, as one moves towards the interface, the energy of Ti d 3 bands are lowered in energy, in a layer-by-layer fashion and one observes that the d 3 bands emanating from the interface Ti ions cross the Fermi energy.
Thus, the Fermi energy is composed of surface O p 2 bands as well as interface Ti d 3 bands.
This is consistent with the predictions of the polar catastrophe model, suggesting an electronic reconstruction of the interface Ti bands via transfer of electrons from the LaAlO 3 film.

In case of LaAlO /SrHfO 3 hetero-structures, we find no band cross- ing at the Fermi energy. The ground state is insulating with an electronic band gap of 2.6 eV. It may be noted that the estimated band gap from the calculations may be significantly underestimated, in the light of the knowledge that the experimentally measured SrTiO 3 band gap of 3.2 eV is ≃40% smaller (1.9 eV) in the GGA calculations. Similarly, the calculated GGA band gap of bulk SrHfO 3 in its cubic perovskite structure is determined to be 3.8 eV against the experi- mental value of 6.1 eV [30], i.e., ≃37% underestimation with regard to experimental value. However, the exact value of the electronic band gap seems to be of little relevance in the present context. Irrespective of the band gap underestimation, first-principles calculations employing both local density approximation (LDA) or GGA consistently reproduce the critical thickness of 4 unit-cells of LaAlO 3 to impart conductivity at the LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 hetero-interface . In , we show the partial density of states (PDOS) of the Hf and Ti sub-lattice of the 4 unit-cell thick LaAlO /SrHfO
are in good agreement with those reported in Ref. panel). The horizontal line through energy zero represents the reference Fermi energy.

(Color Online) PDOS of LaAlO − SrHfO 3 3(left panel) and LaAlO − SrTiO 3 3(right panel). It shows layer resolved DOS calculated using GGA. The zero on the energy scale represent the E F . [21]. As evident, from the figure, the interface
Ti d 3 states cross the E F , while in LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 no finite states are observed at E F .
Beyond, a comparison of the LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 and LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3
band structures show that there is a rigid band like shift of the transition metals d -states in the conduction band.
However, such a case is not true for the O p 2 bands that constitute the upper valence band.
They are at variance in both dispersion as well as in position from the Fermi energy.

While in LaAlO /SrHfO 3 , the surface AlO 2 emanating O p 2 are more dispersed over the energy range of −0.5 to +0.1 eV(E=0 referring to the reference Fermi energy, E f ), they appear to much narrower in LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 with a dispersion range between −0.1 eV to E F .

This unequivocally suggests that the energy scales associated with valence band alignment of LaAlO 3 to that of the substrate SrXO 3 conduction bands are very different, although the interface of both LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 and LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 hetero-structures develop similar polar-discontinuity.

Despite having a polar discontinuity at the interface of LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 hetero-structure, the question is "what then relaxes the polar instability developed at the hetero-interface of LaAlO /SrHfO 3 3 " To address, we seek explanation within the realms of parallel plate capacitor model.

For two infinitely extended oppositely charged plates separated by distance d , which here represents the inter-planar (LaO) + and (AlO) − distance, the potential V d ∝ , assuming that both charge and the dielectric constant remains unchanged.
In this backdrop, it is also important to note that a change in dielectric constant is possible in these systems due to lattice strain.
In compar- ison to the LaAlO /SrHfO 3 which has a lattice mismatch of ≃3%, for LaAlO /SrHfO 3 this amounts to ≃8%, evidencing large strain at the hetero-interface.

Beyond, it is generally found that compressive strain decreases the dielectric constant in the perovskite structure, while the tensile strain enhances the dielectric constant in a parallel plate capacitor .
We also note that system with much larger interface strain have been synthesized and characterized.
For example, a comparison of the lattice constant of SrZrO 3 and SrTiO 3 mounts to a 6% mismatch, however, have been successfully grown by various groups.

To investigate whether structural distortion and/or atomic relaxa- tion play any role in alleviating the polar catastrophe at the hetero- interface, we carry out the structure optimization for the hetero- structures by using force optimization using the scalar-relativistic Hamiltonian. In these, we discover interesting features relevant to the present discussion. In we show the change in the cationic inter-planar distance of both LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 and LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 hetero-structures. What follows from is a systematic variation in the negatively ) and positively (La 3+ O 2− ) charged inter- planar distances along the crystallographic c-axis, as one move from the surface LaAlO 3 to the SrXO 3 substrate. We find that the Al-Al c- axial ionic distance is compressed significantly in LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 , far more higher in comparison with its isoelectronic LaAlO /SrTiO 3 system. For instance, the Al-Al c-axial bond distance near to the surface is twice larger compressed in LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 than LaAlO 3 / SrTiO 3 . However, as one approaches the LaO -TiO 2 hetero-interface from the surface, the distance between the AlO 2 planes decrease, converging to their equilibrium value.
Similarly, marked deviation in the inter-ionic c-axial distances are also observed between the La-La ions which constitute the film overlayers.
The relaxation of the TiO 2 (HfO 2 ) planes in the respective SrTiO 3 (SrHfO 3 ), however, appears to be less altered owing to their charge.
Thus, it follows that maximum bonding modulations are observed at the two interfaces, i.e.,
(i) at the hetero-interface of non- polar TiO 2 with polar LaO layer and,
(ii) that at the polar AlO layer of the LaAlO 3 film surface with vacuum.
The maximum compression is, however, observed in the proximity of the negatively charged AlO 2 - vacuum interface.
Although small, the change in the X-X bond distances of the substrate along the c-axis, in the hetero-interfacial region are also of certain importance.

Considering the atomic-mass of Hf, a displacement of such massive ions from its equilibrium position amounts to higher energy, the source of which is derived from the energy associated with the built-in interface polar discontinuity.
Thus, we find at least two intrinsic mechanisms that prevail in such oxide hetero-structures, which compete accordingly to the nature of the ions that represent the hetero-interface.

Since, the Ti ions in TiO 2 terminated SrTiO 3 have a greater propensity to form multi-valent states, the potential build-up due to polar discontinuity in LaAlO / SrTiO 3 hetero-structure is partly alleviated by means of both atomic relaxation as well as electronic reconstruction.
The electronic recon- struction facilitates conductivity at the hetero-interface in the form of a quasi-two dimensional electron gas.

Along these perspectives, the absence of hetero-interface conductivity in LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 reflects to the impedance of Hf 4+ ⟶ Hf 3+ chemical reduction, although the ionization potential of Hf ion is smaller than that of Ti.
The impedance of Hf 3+ in the interfacial HfO 2 layers of the SrHfO 3 substrate appears to be associated with steric interactions.
As per empirical calculations, the ionic radius of Hf 4+ (91 pm) upon reduction to Hf 3+ increases to 103 pm, which may not fit into the lattice .

Thus, with the in- plane lattice parameter being constrained to that of the substrate, the polar catastrophe which mounts with LaAlO 3 film thickness is alle- viated along the c-axis, with decreasing inter-planar distance towards the surface from the hetero-interface.
Such a relaxation abide by the parallel plate capacitor model characteristics.
The flow of charge from the AlO 2 surface could be impeded by decreasing the distance between the negatively charged AlO 2 and positively charge LaO plates, accord- ing to the basic relation V d ∝ .
Consequently, as the distance between the charged plates are decreased, the potential build-up at the hetero- interface would also decrease.
These results, derived out of our first- principles calculations point to a direction of experimental validation so as to ascertain
(i) the importance of multi-valent ions at the hetero- interfaces for 2DEG,
(ii) relevance of structural relaxation (and/or atomic reconstruction) at both hetero-interface and at hetero-surface.

To summarize, the interface properties of polar-nonpolar LaAlO / SrTiO 3 and LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 hetero-structures are studied within the realms of DFT methods. With 4f electrons of Hf ions partly screening the valence charge, the ionization potential of Hf ions is significantly lowered and thus expected that the polarity driven interface potential would drive in a quasi-two dimensional electron gas at the hetero- interface of LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 , similar to its isoelectronic LaAlO 3 /SrTiO 3 counterpart. However, formation of non-equilibrium Hf 3+ states are forbidden in the LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 , rendering the interface insulating. The electrostatic potential build-up at the interface is, in turn, nullified
δd (Angstroms) .

The deviation in the inter-ionic distances between the negatively charged (AlO 2 ) - planes, positively charged (LaO) + planes and charge neutral XO (X=Ti and Hf) and SrO planes along the crystallographic c-axis in LaAlO 3 -SrTiO 3 and LaAlO 3 -SrHfO 3 hetero- structures, from the fully relaxed force optimized structure, in comparison to the their bulk cubic perovskite value (3.905 Å for SrTiO 3 and 4.117 for SrHfO 3 ).
The X-X ionic distances in the upper panel refer to the Ti-Ti and Hf-Hf bond distances of the respective hetero-structure.
The dashed lines serve as a guide to the eye.

by inter-planar ionic relaxation. Calculations reveal that the inter- planar distance between the charged (AlO 2 ) − and (LaO) + planes of the LaAlO 3 /SrHfO 3 hetero-structure are renormalized, with the planes near the surface being significantly compressed. This is in tandem with the parallel plate capacitor model, where the electrostatic potential proportionate with inter-planar distance (V d ∝ ). A decrease in d therefore reduces the extent of polar catastrophe at the interface. Thus, our calculations infer that the polar catastrophe may be necessary criteria for an oxide hetero-interface to display quasi- 2DEG, however, is not sufficient. Nevertheless, it is the propensity of transition metal ions to exhibit multi-valent states, the most necessary criteria and in cases where inter-valence transition is suppressed, the electrostatic instability due to polar discontinuity is compensated by means of structural modulations.
